page.title: 11 WANDLEBURY
page.content: Wandlebury, once the country seat of Lord Godolphin, was bought by the Cambridge Preservation Society in 1954 to protect it from development. Once an Iron Age Hill fort, one of the ditches thet surrounded the village can be seen on the top of the hill. Of 53 acres of grass only half an acre of original grassland remains. All the trees were planted. Over 90% of the archaeological sites have been spoilt by gardening and building. Ditches were filled in and inner banks removed. In 1975 it was designated a "country park". Paths were put through trees and meadows attracting visitors. The tail of a Wellington bomber is stuck high up in a beech tree, where it crashed in fog in World War 2. At the far end of the reserve is a Roman road part of which is an SSSI because of its rich chalk flora.
